The Office of Congressional Ethics has an important role to play in restoring confidence in Congress, and it will continue to perform its work in the new Congress as the Office of Congressional Complaint Review. As the incoming Chairwoman of the House Committee on Ethics, I will work in a bipartisan manner with the Office to ensure its independence and to maintain the highest ethical standards of the House. I will not interfere with the bipartisan independent board that governs the Office or prevent it from doing its work. Read more about the proposed changes here: http://susanwbrooks.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/brooks-the-oce-has-an-important-role-to-play-in-restoring-confidence-in

I applaud the decision to remove the proposed reforms to the Office of Congressional Ethics from the House Rules voted on today. Many of these reforms are worthy of discussion and debate, and as incoming Chairwoman of the House Ethics Committee I am committed to working with my colleagues on the House Ethics Committee to come to a bipartisan agreement on a path forward. Together, we can preserve the independence of the Office of Congressional Ethics, maintain the highest ethical standards of the House, and ensure that the American people are informed. http://www.chronicle-tribune.com/news/brooks-did-not-support-gutting-oce/article_edaa67d1-cae0-51b6-8360-1a25fce9b6cc.html

Obamacare isn't working - health care costs are on the rise, premiums are increasing and everyone, including Hoosiers, has fewer choices when it comes to insurance. In practice that means that this year, Hoosiers are having to decide between paying hundreds of dollars more each month for health insurance and keeping their plan and their doctors. We must repeal and replace Obamacare before it gets worse. There will be a stable transition to a better, 21st century health care system that will make health insurance more affordable and accessible for people while also giving you more choices when it comes to your health. Getting government out of the way of our businesses, large and small, so that they can continue to innovate, grow and create jobs is one of our A Better Way priorities. In the first two weeks of the 115th Congress, we've passed three bills with my support aimed a providing regulatory relief to help our economy grow and ensuring that regulations enacted in the future will have a positive impact on our country's growth. The Regulatory Accountability Act, the REINS Act and the Midnight Rules Relief Act will enhance Congressional oversight of rules with more than a $100 million impact, require greater opportunity for public input and vetting, and require agencies to account for the direct, indirect and cumulative impacts of new regulations on small businesses, among other things. Tonight, the House, with my support, will take action to prevent Americans from receiving fraudulent calls or text messages from unscrupulous telemarketers and scammers. Spoofing occurs when a caller deliberately falsifies caller ID information, and it is often used to trick someone into giving away personal or private information which can then be illegally sold or used in fraud activity. H.R 423, the Anti-Spoofing Act of 2017, expands current prohibitions to prevent any person or entity from transmitting misleading or inaccurate caller ID information using text messaging or Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) with the intent to defraud, cause harm, or wrongly obtain anything of value. Read more about this bill here: https://policy.house.gov/legislative/bills/hr-423-anti-spoofing-act-2017

Keeping our country safe should be our top priority, and I agree that we must do more to improve our vetting process for foreign nationals and refugees who wish to come to our country, especially from places where terrorist organizations are active and governments are unstable or nonexistent. We know that jihadists and terrorists are using our immigration and refugee resettlement programs to infiltrate and attack our homeland. It is up to us to ensure that their efforts to do so are unsuccessful, and increased scrutiny of people traveling to the United States from such places is one way to accomplish this goal. However, I do not believe in discrimination, I do not support a religious test for immigrants or refugees, and I do support our nation's refugee resettlement program. America is a nation of immigrants, and our diversity has always been one of our greatest strengths. I join my colleagues in Congress in calling on the Administration for more information and clarity around the impact of the temporary provisions in the executive order on people who already have visas or who have previously been granted legal status.

In celebration of Black History Month, I’m going to highlight notable black Hoosiers, their accomplishments and contributions to our state and country each day on Twitter. Be sure to follow @susanwbrooks to learn more about our shared Hoosier history and to celebrate #BlackHistoryMonth with me. Today, we’re honoring the Armstrong family of Westfield, Indiana. Jefferson Armstrong, a former slave from Missouri, arrived in Westfield in 1873. He had 5 sons with his third wife, Sarah, and all 5 served in World War I. The Armstrongs were the only family in Indiana with 5 sons wearing the American military uniform at the same time during the war. The second oldest, Sgt. Irven Armstrong was a life-long educator. During his service in 1918, his students at IPS #17 wrote him letters which are the inspiration behind the Indiana Historical Society play, 'Sincerely, Sgt. Armstrong.' Sgt. Armstrong returned to Indianapolis after the war and continued to teach. He retired as head of the History Department at Crispus Attucks High School in 1959, and following retirement, he taught veterans of the Vietnam War.

At a recent event in Anderson, a mom brought me a photo of her daughter, a young woman with a pre-existing condition. She was concerned about her daughter’s ability to have healthcare coverage in the future. Today, I joined House Committee on Energy and Commerce Chairman Greg Walden as an original co-sponsor on a bill that protects her daughter, and the countless other Hoosiers who have pre-existing conditions, from astronomically high premiums and lost benefits based on how healthy or sick they may be. H.R. 1121, the Pre-Existing Conditions Protection Act of 2017, reaffirms guaranteed healthcare access, ensures that enrollees cannot have benefits excluded from a plan due to a pre-existing condition, and that patients will not pay more based off of how healthy or sick they may be.

Obamacare is broken. The individual market is collapsing under its own weight, and more insurers are refusing to participate in state exchanges leaving people without options and facing difficult decisions about the kind of healthcare coverage they can afford for themselves and their families. Certainly, some Americans benefited from the law, but far more Americans have been failed by it and are demanding relief. Wednesday’s House Committee on Energy and Commerce markup will begin the process of repealing this failed policy and rebuilding a healthcare system that is more accessible and affordable for Hoosiers. This week I've gotten a lot of questions and concerns about online privacy and the impact of S.J. Res 34. First and foremost, let me explain that S.J. Res. 34, if signed into law by the President, has no net impact on your online privacy. S.J. Res 34 overturns a regulation finalized under the Obama Administration that was never implemented. Overturning the regulation, before it takes effect, restores consistency to our internet privacy rules and maintains the FTC's ability to continue to protect your privacy online, a job the FTC has been doing since the internet was created. On the last day of #BreastCancerAwarenessMonth, please take a moment to read about a #breastcancer #Hoosier survivor: Michelle.   Michelle was a working, single-mother from Indianapolis, Indiana when her doctor found a cancerous cluster of cells in her breast. When Michelle shared her story with me, she explained how she never would have gone in for a mammogram at only 35 years old if it had not been covered by her insurance because she was unaware of a history of breast cancer in her family until after her diagnosis. After seeing a story in the IndyStar featuring the Indy SurviveOars, Michelle joined this group of #breastcancersurvivors and has found solace and comfort being able to talk with women going through the same struggles she has faced. The Indy SurviveOars is a group of local breast cancer survivors who practice dragon boat racing on Geist Reservoir in Indianapolis. I had the opportunity to join them at a practice earlier this year and meet Michelle.   While it’s easy to believe that Michelle’s diagnosis at such a young age is an outlier, unfortunately, Michelle’s story is all too common. There’s no way to predict if and when a woman will find cancerous cells in her breast. She could be 20, 30, 40, or 50 years old, the fact is we just don’t know. The Indiana State Department of Health reports that in Indiana alone, there are 4,400 new cases of breast cancer diagnosed each year. 4,400 Hoosiers who have to seek treatment, and fight for their lives. That’s 4,400 too many, but the good news is that early detection and diagnosis can lead to treatment. Many members of the Indy SurviveOars were diagnosed with breast cancer in their 30’s and 40’s, and they only discovered the cancer as a result of regular screenings, including mammograms.   Without a diagnosis, breast cancer can be fatal. But we do know that screening saves lives and that early detection helps women beat breast cancer. According to the American Cancer Society, “Breast cancer that’s found early, when it’s small and has not spread, is easier to treat successfully. Getting regular screening tests is the most reliable way to find breast cancer early.”   In 2009, the United States Preventative Services Task Force (USPSTF) updated its guidelines to: (1) recommend against routine annual screening mammograms for women between 40 and 49 years old; and (2) recommend for biannual instead of annual screening mammograms for women between 70 and 74 years old. I believe the USPSTF’s recommendations are wrong and could limit critical access to lifesaving breast exams for millions of women.  That is why I introduced the Protecting Access to Lifesaving Screenings Act (PALS Act), in the House earlier this year. This important bill would prevent the USPSTF from limiting access to screening mammograms. The provisions in the bill were included in Section 226 of the final fiscal year 2017 appropriations bill that President Donald J. Trump signed into law on May 5, 2017. I am proud to have gotten the PALS Act language included in the final appropriations bill and postponing USPSTF’s misguided guidelines from taking effect until January 1, 2019. Since the PALS Act was signed into law as part of an appropriations bill, this is just a temporary fix. I will continue working to ensure a long-term fix that protects insurance coverage of screening mammograms for the millions of women like Michelle who need them.

The final conference agreement between the Senate and House on #taxreform has been signed and is anticipated to be voted on this week. We are one step closer to providing  #IN05 Hoosiers with much needed tax relief. The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (H.R. 1) will deliver historic tax relief for Americans across the country and will boost our nation's economy. This is a pro-family, pro-growth bill. It expands the Child Tax Credit from $1,000 to $2,000 for single filers and married couples to help parents with the cost of raising children. The #tax credit is refundable up to $1,400.  Combined with the new doubled standard deduction, families on the lowest end of the income spectrum will be able to keep more of their paychecks. It also preserves the Child and Dependent Care Tax Credit and the Adoption Tax Credit.  For those across the country who face expensive medical bills, our tax plan expands the medical expense deduction for 2018 and 2019 for medical expenses exceeding 7.5 percent of adjusted gross income, and continues to 10 percent beginning in 2020. https://fairandsimple.gop/

Today is a monumental day for our country. For the first time in 31 years, we’ve simplified the #taxcode and passed significant tax cuts to benefit American families, workers and businesses.  I believe our communities thrive when our colleagues, neighbors, friends and loved ones have the freedom to pursue their dreams. The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act is family focused and allows taxpayers to plan for their futures. It will lower the tax burden for many individuals and families in Indiana so #Hoosiers can keep more of their hard-earned money.  We’ve provided unprecedented tax relief for American families by eliminating the ‘marriage penalty,’ increasing the child tax credit from $1,000 to $2,000 per child, and expanding the medical expenses deduction for those who face high medical bills.  Our bill improves saving opportunities for education by allowing families to use 529 accounts to save for elementary, secondary and higher education. This bill does not tax graduate students on any reduced or free tuition they may receive from their institution.  The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act is about encouraging the establishment and expansion of American small businesses. It allows for immediate expensing of new equipment to grow and improve their operations and provides a 20 percent deduction on pass-through businesses. Small businesses and start-up companies need the lower tax rates this bill delivers in order to thrive and prosper so they can create jobs, raise wages and grow our economy.  Settling for the status-quo is not an option. I am proud of my vote today that will help provide security for families and small businesses across the nation.
